query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Avvegna che la subitana fuga 2 dispergesse color per la campagna, 3 rivolti al monte ove ragion ne fruga,
4 i’ mi ristrinsi a la fida compagna: 5 e come sare’ io sanza lui corso? 6 chi m’avria tratto su per la montagna?
7 El mi parea da sé stesso rimorso: 8 o dignitosa coscïenza e netta, 9 come t’è picciol fallo amaro morso!
10 Quando li piedi suoi lasciar la fretta, 11 che l’onestade ad ogn’ atto dismaga, 12 la mente mia, che prima era ristretta,
13 lo ’ntento rallargò, sì come vaga, 14 e diedi ’l viso mio incontr’ al poggio 15 che ’nverso ’l ciel più alto si dislaga.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Although the sudden flight 2 scattered those people across the countryside, 3 we turned towards the mountain where reason urges us,
4 I drew close to my faithful companion: 5 and how could I have run without him? 6 who would have led me up the mountain?
7 He seemed to me remorseful of himself: 8 oh dignified and pure conscience, 9 how a small fault is a bitter pang to you!
10 When his feet abandoned their haste, 11 which propriety saps from every action, 12 my mind, which was previously restricted,
13 expanded its intention, as if eager, 14 and I turned my face towards the hill 15 that rises highest towards the sky.
**Cornish:**
1 Erbynnas an tebel flogan dowr 2 a dhiberthas an bobel a-dreus an pow, 3 ni a droas dhe'n menydh lemmyn ni a-houl,
4 ow kewsel dhe'n kever chywir fydhlon: 5 ha marow vythsa heb ytho? 6 pandra vyth a-hweg dhe'n menydh?
7 Ytho dhe'n kever owth a-dhiwedhes gans y honan: 8 ow koweth teg ha glan, 9 marow byghan yw peth owth a-dhiwedhes dhe'th!
10 Pandra y dreus a-berthas an flogan, 11 owth a-dhiberth an onester an pub tra, 12 owth a-dhiberth ow menow, owth a-dhiwedhes kyns,
13 a-dhiberthas ow entent, marow owth a-hwhel, 14 ha owth a-droas ow hweg dhe'n bry, 15 owth a-dhiberth an ughella dhe'n nef.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 Lo sol, che dietro fiammeggiava roggio, 17 rotto m’era dinanzi a la figura, 18 ch’avëa in me de’ suoi raggi l’appoggio.
query.result:
**English:**
16 The sun, which was flaming red behind me, 17 was broken in front of me by the figure, 18 which had the support of its rays in me.
**Cornish:**
16 An howl, owth a-flamm ow roug, 17 a-dhiberthas ow kensa dhe'm, 18 owth a-gavas dhe'n kever an skoedh a'y rousow.

**English:**
19 I turned to the side with fear 20 of being abandoned, when I saw 21 only the dark earth in front of me;
22 and my comfort began to say to me, 23 turning to me completely: 24 "don't you believe that I am with you and that I am guiding you?
25 Evening is already there where the body 26 in which I cast a shadow is buried; 27 Naples has it, and it is taken from Brindisi.
**Cornish:**
19 Owth a-droas dhe'n tu dhe goel gans ofn 20 a-vesa gwedhys, pan welyn 21 an nor dhe'm an tir tywyll;
22 ha ow koforth: "Rag whai'th owth a-dhiffydh?", 23 a-leverel dhe'm a-dhalleth dhe'm oll; 24 "na gryssi'th ow vy gansos ha owth a-dhiwedha'th?",
25 An gorthugher yw genna lemmyn le mayth 26 an korf a-bervedh owth a-wrug ow skedh; 27 Napoli a'y gavas, ha a-dhiberthas a Vrandizio.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Ora, se innanzi a me nulla s’aombra, 29 non ti maravigliar più che d’i cieli 30 che l’uno a l’altro raggio non ingombra.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Now, if nothing casts a shadow before me, 29 do not be more amazed than at the heavens 30 that one does not obstruct the rays of the other.
**Cornish:**
28 Mes, mar nyns eus nevra dhe'm owth a-skoedh, 29 na wra'th ow magh dhe goel ages a'n nefow, 30 owth a-dhiberth an eil y gila dhe'n gila.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 A sofferir tormenti, caldi e geli 32 simili corpi la Virtù dispone 33 che, come fa, non vuol ch’a noi si sveli.
query.result:
**English:**
31 To suffer torments, hot and cold, 32 the Virtuous One disposes similar bodies 33 that, as she does, she does not want to reveal to us.
**Cornish:**
31 Rag dhe dhugga poenys, tomm ha yen, 32 an Virtus a-dhiposa korfow par, 33 owth a-wul, marow hi a-wul, na wra'th dhe'n ni dhe dhiskwedhes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Matto è chi spera che nostra ragione 35 possa trascorrer la infinita via 36 che tiene una sustanza in tre persone.
query.result:
**English:**
34 Foolish is he who hopes that our reason 35 can traverse the infinite path 36 that a substance holds in three persons.
**Cornish:**
34 Fol yw an kever a-wul ow reson 35 a-alli dhe drehedhes an fordh anfeth 36 owth a-berth sustans yn tri person.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 State contenti, umana gente, al quia; 38 ché, se potuto aveste veder tutto, 39 mestier non era parturir Maria;
40 e disïar vedeste sanza frutto 41 tai che sarebbe lor disio quetato, 42 ch’etternalmente è dato lor per lutto:
43 io dico d’Aristotile e di Plato 44 e di molt’ altri»; e qui chinò la fronte, 45 e più non disse, e rimase turbato.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Be content, human race, with the quia; 38 because, if you could have seen everything, 39 it would not have been necessary for Mary to give birth;
40 and you saw in vain the desire 41 of those whose desire would have been quenched, 42 who are eternally given mourning:
43 I speak of Aristotle and Plato 44 and many others"; and here he bowed his head, 45 and said no more, and remained troubled.
**Cornish:**
37 Bosowgh dhe vos, bobel dhodho, gans an quia; 38 rag, mar peusoch a-weles pub tra, 39 nyns eus mester dhe Varia dhe dhaskel;
40 ha'gas a-welas an dysir heb ffrwyth 41 re beu an ffrwyth dhe'n dysir, 42 owth a-dhiberthas dhe'n poenys byth:
43 ow leverel a Aristotles ha Plato 44 ha leel erel"; ha ena y'gann y ben, 45 ha nyns leveras moy, ha y'gann trubys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Noi divenimmo intanto a piè del monte; 47 quivi trovammo la roccia sì erta, 48 che ’ndarno vi sarien le gambe pronte.
query.result:
**English:**
46 We came to the foot of the mountain in the meantime; 47 there we found the rock so steep, 48 that even nimble legs would have been in vain.
**Cornish:**
46 Ni a-dhiwiskas yn keth dhe'n menydh; 47 ena ni a-gavas an garrek mar ughel, 48 owth a-veu an keth dhe'n garrek mar sprus.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Tra Lerice e Turbìa la più diserta, 50 la più rotta ruina è una scala, 51 verso di quella, agevole e aperta.
query.result:
**English:**
49 Between Lerici and Turbia the most deserted, 50 the most broken landslide is a staircase, 51 compared to that one, easy and open.
**Cornish:**
49 Ynter Lerice ha Turbìa an moy difeyth, 50 an moy torrys ruina yw skell, 51 dhe geverel dhe henna, es ha aghes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 «Or chi sa da qual man la costa cala», 53 disse ’l maestro mio fermando ’l passo, 54 «sì che possa salir chi va sanz’ ala?».
query.result:
**English:**
52 "Now who knows from which hand the slope descends", 53 said my master, stopping his step, 54 "so that he who goes without wings can climb it?".
**Cornish:**
52 "Mes pandra a wydh a-berth an garrek a-hwhel", 53 a leveras ow mester a-sevel y gam, 54 "marow a-alli dhe sevel an kever heb esel?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 E mentre ch’e’ tenendo ’l viso basso 56 essaminava del cammin la mente, 57 e io mirava suso intorno al sasso,
58 da man sinistra m’apparì una gente 59 d’anime, che movieno i piè ver’ noi, 60 e non pareva, sì venïan lente.
query.result:
**English:**
55 And while I was keeping my face down, 56 examining the path in my mind, 57 and I was looking up around the rock,
58 on my left hand side there appeared to me a group 59 of souls, who were moving their feet towards us, 60 and they didn't seem to be coming quickly.
**Cornish:**
55 Ha pan vynnavow an fas dhesel, 56 ow provia an fordh yn ow myn, 57 ha my a welas dhe-ves an garrek,
58 war-lergh ow dhewlav a welas 59 bagas a eneval, ow tos ow tros dhe-nugyn, 60 ha nyns eus ow tos yn skoodh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 «Leva», diss’ io, «maestro, li occhi tuoi: 62 ecco di qua chi ne darà consiglio, 63 se tu da te medesmo aver nol puoi».
query.result:
**English:**
61 "Lift up," I said, "master, your eyes: 62 behold, over there is someone who will give us advice, 63 if you cannot get it from yourself."
**Cornish:**
61 "Codh," meuris, "mester, dha lyga: 62 sel neb ow kodha dhe-nugyn a wra gonsel dhe-nugyn, 63 mar nyns eus ow kodha hy dhe-dhys."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Guardò allora, e con libero piglio 65 rispuose: «Andiamo in là, ch’ei vegnon piano; 66 e tu ferma la spene, dolce figlio».
query.result:
**English:**
64 He looked then, and with a free manner 65 he replied: "Let us go over there, for they are coming slowly; 66 and you, sweet son, keep your hope firm."
**Cornish:**
64 Ev a welas ena, ha gans frank 65 ev a leveris: "Ew dhe-nugyn, rag yns eus ow tos yn skoodh; 66 ha tisoma, karrek vyghan, gwesta dha spyrans."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Ancora era quel popol di lontano, 68 i’ dico dopo i nostri mille passi, 69 quanto un buon gittator trarria con mano,
70 quando si strinser tutti ai duri massi 71 de l’alta ripa, e stetter fermi e stretti 72 com’ a guardar, chi va dubbiando, stassi.
query.result:
**English:**
67 That group of people was still far away, 68 I say after our thousand steps, 69 as far as a good thrower would throw with his hand,
70 when they all gathered at the hard rocks 71 of the high bank, and stood still and close together 72 as someone who is going doubtfully stands to watch.
**Cornish:**
67 An gwella pobel o pell, 68 wosa niver mil kamm, 69 kepar dell a wra tas gans y gila.
70 Pan wrug yntra yn-nans dhe'n garrek kalet 71 a'n garrek ughel, ha sevel fest ha nans, 72 kepar den a wra mos dhe welas, ow sevel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 «O ben finiti, o già spiriti eletti», 74 Virgilio incominciò, «per quella pace 75 ch’i’ credo che per voi tutti s’aspetti,
76 ditene dove la montagna giace, 77 sì che possibil sia l’andare in suso; 78 ché perder tempo a chi più sa più spiace».
query.result:
**English:**
73 "O well-ended ones, or already chosen spirits," 74 Virgil began, "by that peace 75 which I believe is awaited for all of you,
76 tell us where the mountain lies, 77 so that it may be possible to go up; 78 for losing time is most displeasing to those who know more."
**Cornish:**
73 "O tiwethes da, po spyrysow ethol," 74 Virjili a dhallathas, "gans an hedh 75 a grysaf y vos oll dhe dhiskwedhes,
76 leveris dhe-nugyn le may hy'n menydh, 77 mar a wra possybyl dhe vos dhe-ves; 78 rag kolli amser dhe'n neb a wydh moy yw moy dhesplesys."

**English:**
79 As the little sheep come out of the fold 80 one by one, two by two, and three by three, and the others stand 81 timidly, lowering their eyes and noses;
82 and what the first one does, the others do, 83 crowding against her if she stops, 84 simple and quiet, and they do not know why;
85 so I saw the head of that fortunate flock 86 begin to move forward then, 87 modest in countenance and dignified in gait.
**Cornish:**
79 Kepar an avalow a dheuth magh a'n clos 80 unn ha unn, dew ha tri, ha'n erel a sevel 81 ow sparnia, ow lettya aga lagha ha'ga fri.
82 Ha'n tra a wra an kynsa, an erel a wra, 83 ow tos dhe'y hy, mar hy a sevel, 84 sempel ha tas, ha nyns eus ow tos an pow.
85 Henwys vy dhe welas penn an bagas a lowen 86 ow tos dhe-nugyn ena, 87 pudyk yn aga fas ha onest yn aga kerdhes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Come color dinanzi vider rotta 89 la luce in terra dal mio destro canto, 90 sì che l’ombra era da me a la grotta,
91 restaro, e trasser sé in dietro alquanto, 92 e tutti li altri che venieno appresso, 93 non sappiendo ’l perché, fenno altrettanto.
query.result:
**English:**
88 As those in front saw the light broken 89 on the ground to my right side, 90 so that the shadow was from me to the cave,
91 they stopped, and drew themselves back a little, 92 and all the others who were coming behind, 93 not knowing why, did the same.
**Cornish:**
88 Kepar an re a welas an golon torrys 89 an golon war an nor dhe'm dhewlath, 90 kepar an skewens o'm dhe'n ogof,
91 y feuas sevel, ha mos dhe'n-nans y gila, 92 ha oll an erel a dheuth wosa, 93 hebma tos an pow, a wrug an keth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 «Sanza vostra domanda io vi confesso 95 che questo è corpo uman che voi vedete; 96 per che ’l lume del sole in terra è fesso.
query.result:
**English:**
94 "Without your asking, I confess to you 95 that this is a human body that you see; 96 because of which the light of the sun is broken on the ground.
**Cornish:**
94 "Hebm' aga govyn, vy a gonfessaf 95 hemma yw korf denel a welowgh; 96 rag henna golon an howl yw torrys war an nor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Non vi maravigliate, ma credete 98 che non sanza virtù che da ciel vegna 99 cerchi di soverchiar questa parete».
query.result:
**English:**
97 Do not marvel, but believe 98 that not without virtue that comes from heaven 99 do I seek to overcome this wall.
**Cornish:**
97 Na vynnowgh bos, mes kredes 98 na heb vyrtys a dheuth a'n nef 99 y hwelaf dhe drehedhes an garrek ma.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Così ’l maestro; e quella gente degna 101 «Tornate», disse, «intrate innanzi dunque», 102 coi dossi de le man faccendo insegna.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Thus the master; and that worthy people 101 "Turn back," he said, "enter before us then," 102 making a sign with the backs of their hands.
**Cornish:**
100 Henwys an mester; ha'n bobel a lowen 101 "Tro'dhwgh," ev a leveris, "mos dhe-nugyn ena," 102 ow tos gans aga dhewol ow holya aga dhewol.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 E un di loro incominciò: «Chiunque 104 tu se’, così andando, volgi ’l viso: 105 pon mente se di là mi vedesti unque».
query.result:
**English:**
103 And one of them began: "Whoever 104 you are, going this way, turn your face: 105 consider if you ever saw me down there".**Cornish:**
103 Ha unn dhedha ev commensis: "Pywhag bynnac 104 os ow, ow mos ow mos, tro ha'gas fas: 105 sel an poynt os vythwelow hennagweel".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Io mi volsi ver’ lui e guardail fiso: 107 biondo era e bello e di gentile aspetto, 108 ma l’un de’ cigli un colpo avea diviso.
query.result:
**English:**
106 I turned to him and looked at him intently: 107 he was blond and handsome and of noble appearance, 108 but one of his eyebrows had been split by a blow.**Cornish:**
106 Yth troys ha'gas ha'gas ev selwelow: 107 ev o blond ha brassa ha gwych y'n edhom, 108 mes unn a'y sourcils o kodha ev colp.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Quand’ io mi fui umilmente disdetto 110 d’averlo visto mai, el disse: «Or vedi»; 111 e mostrommi una piaga a sommo ’l petto.
query.result:
**English:**
109 When I had humbly denied 110 ever having seen him, he said: "Look now"; 111 and he showed me a wound on his chest.**Cornish:**
109 Pythegva yth o humla diswedhes 110 a'y weles bythkweth, ev a leveris: "Weles lemmyn"; 111 ha'gas a dhiskwedhis dhodh war-barth y'n fronk.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Poi sorridendo disse: «Io son Manfredi, 113 nepote di Costanza imperadrice; 114 ond’ io ti priego che, quando tu riedi,
115 vadi a mia bella figlia, genitrice 116 de l’onor di Cicilia e d’Aragona, 117 e dichi ’l vero a lei, s’altro si dice.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Then smiling he said: "I am Manfred, 113 grandson of the Empress Constance; 114 therefore I beg you that, when you return,
115 go to my beautiful daughter, mother 116 of the honor of Sicily and Aragon, 117 and tell her the truth, if other things are being said.**Cornish:**
112 Wosa sourdhans ev a leveris: "My yw Manfredi, 113 nev Costanza an emperoures; 114 rag pyth y'th pyth, pythegva os dyworth,
115 mos dhe dhe'm ver ver vy vrassa verch, mam 116 a enor a Sisili ha Aragon, 117 ha lever dhodh gwir dhe'dhi, mar yw aral leverys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Poscia ch’io ebbi rotta la persona 119 di due punte mortali, io mi rendei, 120 piangendo, a quei che volontier perdona.
query.result:
**English:**
118 After I had my body pierced 119 by two mortal wounds, I surrendered, 120 weeping, to him who willingly forgives.**Cornish:**
118 Wosa yth o torras va person 119 a dhew benn mortal, yth y'm rendis, 120 ow poyntya, dhe'n neb a bardhon gans volons.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Orribil furon li peccati miei; 122 ma la bontà infinita ha sì gran braccia, 123 che prende ciò che si rivolge a lei.
query.result:
**English:**
121 My sins were horrible; 122 but infinite goodness has such long arms, 123 that it embraces whoever turns to it.**Cornish:**
121 Orribyl o va pechodhow; 122 mes an vones da yw kledh avel bras, 123 ha'gas a gemmer neb a dro dhe'dhi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Se ’l pastor di Cosenza, che a la caccia 125 di me fu messo per Clemente allora, 126 avesse in Dio ben letta questa faccia,
127 l’ossa del corpo mio sarieno ancora 128 in co del ponte presso a Benevento, 129 sotto la guardia de la grave mora.
query.result:
**English:**
124 If the shepherd of Cosenza, who was sent 125 to hunt me down by Clement at that time, 126 had read this face well in God,
127 the bones of my body would still be 128 at the head of the bridge near Benevento, 129 under the guard of the heavy pile of stones.**Cornish:**
124 Mar an mester a Gosens, neb o settys 125 dhe'm helghya gans Clemens ena prys, 126 o perthi leel yn da yn Dhew an fas,
127 eskern va'm korf a via bythkweth 128 yn penn an pons ogas dhe Benvento, 129 danvon gwitha an tomm meur a garrek.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Or le bagna la pioggia e move il vento 131 di fuor dal regno, quasi lungo ’l Verde, 132 dov’ e’ le trasmutò a lume spento.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Now the rain soaks them and the wind moves them 131 outside the kingdom, almost along the Verde River, 132 where he changed them into a quenched light.**Cornish:**
130 Lemmyn an glaw a'y golgh ha'gas an gwyns 131 a-ves an rynos, a-hedh dhe'n Gwern, 132 le mayth ev a'y thros dhe golow marow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Per lor maladizion sì non si perde, 134 che non possa tornar, l’etterno amore, 135 mentre che la speranza ha fior del verde.
query.result:
**English:**
133 Because of their curse, eternal love is not lost, 134 so that it cannot return, as long as hope has a flower of green.**Cornish:**
133 Rag an flugh a-dro dhe'n koll, 134 na alla kar an karas an karanteth byth, 135 bythkweth an govonieth a wra glow gwern.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Vero è che quale in contumacia more 137 di Santa Chiesa, ancor ch’al fin si penta, 138 star li convien da questa ripa in fore,
139 per ognun tempo ch’elli è stato, trenta, 140 in sua presunzïon, se tal decreto 141 più corto per buon prieghi non diventa.
query.result:
**English:**
136 It is true that whoever dies in contempt 137 of Holy Church, even if he repents at the end, 138 must stay outside this bank,
139 for as much time as he was, thirtyfold, 140 in his presumption, unless a shorter decree 141 becomes possible through good prayers.**Cornish:**
136 Gwir yw bos mar neb a verw yn kontumaci 137 a'n Eglos Sans, bythkweth mar dhe'n diwedh ev a fenthy, 138 re beu dhe'n omma a-ves an glann-ma,
139 rag pub termyn neb ev o, tregens, 140 yn y breysympti, mar na wra dekred 141 moy korto rag gwell pregow.

**English:**
142 See now if you can make me happy, 143 by revealing to my good Constance 144 how you have seen me, and also this prohibition;
145 for here I am much better off than those over there.
**Cornish:**
142 Gweles yn-lemmyn hag ylli'f vy dhe wul, 143 dre vynhega dhe'm Costanza da 144 kepar hag y'm gweles vy, ha'n-wedhen ma,
145 rag yma vy moy es dhe'n re beu.
